POR.DRECONTENT:
The Strong Motion Downhole Array (SMDA) in Taipei Basin project, conducted by the Institute of Earth Sciences, Academia Sinica, Taipei, Taiwan, comprises a total of 32 strong motion triggered accelerometers spanning eight borehole sites for seismic data collection. Each site has one accelerometer measuring acceleration of motion placed on the surface and two to four lowered by cable to varying depths within narrow shafts bored into the ground and fixed into place with tightly packed sand and mud. There is no other borehole array in a sedimentary basin in the world as is found here. Data received provides a rare 3-D look at the following:

 

  • Propagation or spreading of energy (seismic waves) throughout the sediment
  • Sediment response at varying levels from depth to the surface
  • Observation of increasing levels of shaking (ground motion amplification)
  • Dispersion of energy as it propagates through the earth (attenuation)

 

In order to use the collected data, the orientation (alignment) of each accelerometer must be verified and potentially corrected. The orientations at the surface are known, but those within the boreholes are not. Collected data has shown that orientations of each borehole accelerometer change over time independently of each other.

 

As a Ph.D. student at the Center for Earthquake Research and Information in Memphis, Tennessee, selected to perform research at the Institute of Sciences with the support of the East Asian Pacific Sciences Institute, I began research by developing tools to read, write, and manipulate the data in the computer program MATLAB. After converting the native SMDA data to the standard SAC format used in the United States, I checked the boreholes accelerometers’ orientation using the surface accelerometers as baseline. By exploring various techniques, two methods were chosen for their accuracy in correcting the orientation of each borehole accelerometer. The methods used involved the following:

 

  • Method One—Data from a borehole is rotated iteratively, in a repetitive process, until a maximum correlation between the surface and borehole seismograms is reached.
  • Method Two—Calculations for each accelerometer are made of the apparent azimuth, a measurement of direction, of the first-arriving seismic wave.

 

My project advisor, Dr. Kou-Cheng Chen, director of the SMDA project, and I found that in less than four months, some of the accelerometers had changed orientation by only a few degrees, while others had rotated up to 100 degrees. Though it is clear that each borehole accelerometer may change orientation independently by varying degrees and depths over various lengths of time, it is unknown how quickly each may rotate over time. Other findings revealed a large disparity between ground motion amplification at different frequencies. My research revealed lower frequency ground motion (< 1.5 Hz) was amplified by 4X from depth to the surface, and higher frequency ground motion (>1.5 Hz) was amplified by 7X. This research will become part of my Ph.D. dissertation. Poster presentations were given at the 2011 Summer Institute in Taiwan and the 83rd Annual Meeting of the Eastern Section of the Seismological Society of America. My research regarding these boreholes has been modified to temporal and spatial calibration of Strong Motion Downhole Array in Taipei Basin. Once this situation is resolved, I will begin researching the propagation of seismic waves in the basin.

 

Discovering the need for borehole seismometer calibrations and calibration methods is new knowledge with much intellectual merit and broad impact. As more borehole arrays are built globally, proper calibration is vital for insight into seismic waves’ propagation...
